entry.title: Combined summary - HTLCs using OP_CHECKSEQUENCEVERIFY/OP_LOCKTIMEVERIFY and revocation hashes.
entry.summary: The discussion revolves around the Lightning Network's hash time-locked contracts (HTLCs), which are required for Lightning to be a network. The context explains how each side maintains a commitment transaction with two outputs, one paying to oneself (with some delay), and the second paying to the other side. HTLCs are added to generate these contracts. HTLCs have different lifetimes from commit transactions - this means that while resolving HTLCs off-chain, both parties nominally agree on which way the funds should go, and both the commitment and HTLC are expired simultaneously. If they decide to go to the blockchain, either party can resolve the HTLC by publishing their side of the commitment; so both the commitment and HTLC are executed simultaneously. One of the contributors mentions that with an OP_CSV on both sides of HTLCs, Alice's CSV should time out first. This is because if it doesn't, Eve can try to claim the HTLC funds. In this case, Alice publishes her commitment transaction at T-D-F, and after an additional "D" time units, the time is T-x, at which point Alice can spend the transaction, but Eve cannot. Another contributor adds that threats can be made when there is an OP_CSV on both sides of HTLCs. He says that if someone does not pay him $x to do a cooperative close, he will close unilaterally, thereby locking their funds up. However, he believes that changing the current arrangement would make things marginally worse but no better. Finally, the contributors share a script for HTLC from US to THEM, and HTLC from THEM to US.
